accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction. Questions on literary property rights should be directed to the Special Collections coordinator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p:
Gift of Stanley Clay Walker, April 8, 1978
Accession Number: A78-24

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Stanley Clay Walker was born July 2, 1923, in Norfolk, Va. He attended the Norfolk Public Schools and graduated from Fork Union Military Academy and the Norfolk Business College. When World War II began he enlisted in the United States Army and served in the European Theater.

Following his discharge from service, Walker returned to Norfolk and became a partner in a steel fabricating and engineering firm. He married Sybil Bruce Moore. They had two daughters: Susan Gray Walker Meslang and Elizabeth Tray Walker. Mrs. Walker served on the Board of Visitors, Old Dominion University, from March 30, 1990 to June 30, 1994. Walker served as President of Stanley Walker Associates, Inc. He resided in Norfolk until his death in January 2001.

Walker, a Democrat, began his career in public service as a member of the Norfolk City School Board in 1959. This was shortly after the public schools reopened following the "massive resistance" program. As one who wanted to reform the Democratic party, he became active in a group known as "The Young Turks."

He served on such civic organizations as: Norfolk Cosmopolitan Club; Planning Council of Hampton Roads; Isaac Walton League; Norfolk City Recreation Commission; and, Norfolk Citizen's Advisory Committee. He also served on the Boards of First Virginia Bank of Tidewater; Leigh Memorial Hospital; Salvation Army State Advisory Board; Tidewater Association of Mental Health; and, the Medical Center Hospital.

Walker was elected to a seat in the House of Delegates in 1964 as a Representative of the consolidated 5th, 6th, and 7th districts of Norfolk. He took the oath of office on January 8, 1964, and served four terms there to 1971. In 1971, the Federal Court combined the senatorial districts into one multimember district and Walker took the oath of office as Senator on January 12, 1972. He served from that date until January 2000, representing parts of Norfolk and parts of Virginia Beach in the Sixth Senatorial District.
One aspect of Walker's distinguished career was his service on the Virginia State Crime Commission. He became its first chairman in 1966 and served in that position to 1979.

His office lists his Senate positions as follows: President Pro Tempore: Elected by the Senate in 1988. Only member from Hampton Roads to ever hold this position. Responsibilities include assuming the duties of Lt. Governor in cases of vacancy, disability, or absence; procedural matters of the Senate; appointments to regional and national commissions; member of leadership team which confers with Governor on matters of state.

Standing Committees: Finance, Co-Chairman, and Chairman of the Finance Subcommittee on Education; Education and Health, former Chairman; General Laws, former Chairman; Rules Committee, former Chairman; Privileges and Elections, Joint Rules; Co-Chairman of the Joint Budget Conference Committee made up of four members each from the House and Senate.
Governor's Advisory Council on Revenue Estimates

Legislative Commissions and Joint Committees: Joint Commission on Health Care, Chairman; Joint Legislative Audit and Review, former Chairman; Early Childhood and Child Day Care, Chairman; Equity in Public Education, Chairman; Small Business, Chairman; Reorganization of the Virginia State Library and Archives, Chairman; Future of Transportation in Virginia; State Water; Virginia Housing Study; State and Local Government Responsibility and Taxing Authority; Federal Block Grants; Educational Excellence; Educational Infrastructure; Future of Public Education; Preservation of the Capitol; Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation.

Other Commissions, Boards, State, Regional, National: Senate Presidents' Forum, Board of Directors; Southern Legislative Conference (SLC) Executive Committee; SLC Education Committee, former Chairman; SLC Fiscal Affairs and Government Operations Committee, former Chairman; National Conference of State Legislators (NCSL) Federal Budget and Taxation Committee; NCSL Legislative Management Committee; Southern Regional Education Board; National Leadership Conference; Council of State Governments Intergovernmental Affairs; Southern Growth Policies Board; Elizabeth River Project Leadership Review Board; Jobs for Virginia Graduates, Board of Directors; Planning Council; Sentara Hospitals, Trustee Emeritus; Old Dominion Research Foundation Board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The Walker Papers consist of 35 linear shelf feet in 70 document cases. They deal primarily with his legislative duties as a member of the House of Delegates, 1964-1971 and his service as a member of the Senate from 1972 to 1977, serving parts of Norfolk and parts of Virginia Beach in the Sixth Senatorial District. The political papers include: legislative files, speeches, copies of bills introduced, correspondence, news releases, clippings and studies. They also include the Special (197 1) and Extra (1965 and 1969) Sessions of the General Assembly. The collection spans the years 1959-1977, with the heaviest concentration in the years 1971-1976.

The next substantial portion consists of correspondence (15 boxes). This series, much of it chronologically arranged, reflects the issues before the General Assembly about which constituents expressed their opinions - pro and con. They also indicate his sensitivity to the needs of his constituents and his willingness to assist them wherever possible.

The files of the Virginia State Crime Commission (10 boxes) constitute an extensive and important series. Walker served as first chairman of this commission and held that position from 1966-1979. Specific issues dealt with were: juvenile delinquency; drug and firearms abuse; criminal sex offenders; correctional facilities; pari-mutuel betting; police training; crime prevention; Federal Omnibus Crime Control; and, Safe Streets Act. Walker was also a member of the Council on Criminal Justice that tied in with the accomplishments of the crime commission.

The political files (6 boxes) span the years 1959-1975. They include records of Democratic primaries; political campaigns; general elections; primary and election results; correspondence; organizational structure; financial records; clippings; news releases; platforms; editorials; and, letters of appreciation to supporters. The campaigns were those of. William C. Battle, Clyde L. DuVol II, Joseph T. Fitzgerald, John F. Rixey, William B. Spong, Jr., Albert Teich, and, Stanley Clay Walker. Stanley headed up the Norfolk campaign for Spong in 1966; therefore, there are extensive holdings for his campaign as well as for those of his own.
Walker's speeches and talks (2 boxes) reflect the interest of pending legislation before the General Assembly, the interests of his constituents, and the varied groups before which he spoke.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: Series 1: Correspondence - Boxes 1- 15 (1966-1977) Comprehensive, relating to fellow legislators and responding to concerns of constituency, both personal and matters before the General Assembly on which they expressed opinions.
Series II: Legislative Papers - Boxes 16-48 (1964-1977) Legislative reports and issues.
Sub-series A: General Assembly - Special Session - Boxes 49-50 (1971) 1971: Constitutional Revision
Sub-series B: General Assembly - Extra Sessions - Boxes 51-52 (1965,1969) 1965: Apportionment Act 1969: Constitutional Revision

Series III: Virginia State Crime Commission - Boxes 53-62 (1966-1979) Commission Instructed to: (1) ascertain the causes of crime and recommend ways to reduce and prevent it; (2) explore and recommend means of possible rehabilitation of convicted criminals; (3) study the apprehension, trial and punishment of criminal offenders; and (4) make recommendations as it deems appropriate to the safety and welfare of the citizens of Virginia. The files show how the commission performed its duties.

Series IV: Political Files - Boxes 63-68
Box 63 - 1959-1965
Box 64 - 1966 - Spong Campaign
Box 65 - 1967 - Walker Campaign
Box 66 - 1967 to 1969 - Democratic Campaign
Box 67 - 1969 Primary to 1972 Spong Campaign, News I
Box 68 - 1972 Spong Campaign, News II to 1975 Albert Teich Campaign

Series V - Speeches and Talks - Boxes 69-70
Box 69 - 1963-1970
Box 70- 1971-1973 1967-1968 - Extra copies
